voice: I move in the correct rhythm.
display_name: Channel of Rhythm (5–15) — A Design of Being in the Flow
keynotes: collective rhythm: patterns that support life
sacral fixed pattern meets G-center love of humanity
extremes held inside a dependable routine
distortion: forcing others into your tempo
key to health: stable daily pattern
notes:
Overview: Channel 5–15 links Gate 5 (Fixed Rhythms / Waiting) in the Sacral to Gate 15 (Extremes / Love of Humanity) in the G Center. It sits in the Collective (Understanding) side, so its intelligence is about **what works for everyone over time**, not just for the individual. This is why Ra called it “a design of being in the flow.” When it’s correct, this channel literally modulates the environmental tempo for others.

Line Companion / Jovian-style pulls (≤25 words):
1) "Gate 5 is fixed patterns and natural rhythms." — Ra Uru Hu, Line Companion (Gate 5)
2) "Waiting is powerful." — Ra Uru Hu, Line Companion (Gate 5)
3) "Gate 15 is the love of humanity." — Ra Uru Hu, Line Companion (Gate 15)
4) "The gate of extremes." — Ra Uru Hu, Line Companion (Gate 15)
5) "A design of being in the flow." — Ra Uru Hu, Channel 5–15

Interpretation of the quotes:
- Gate 5 wants predictable, dependable timing — sleep, food, sex, work, practice.
- Gate 15 can live (and love) **any** extreme — very slow, very fast, very social, very hermit — but it loves what is **natural**.
- Together, 5–15 creates a person whose **natural beat** helps the collective find a healthy rhythm.

Mechanics:
- **Sacral (5)** provides sustainable energy for patterns.
- **G (15)** provides the capacity to embrace and normalize human extremes.
- In combination, the body becomes an environmental metronome: your presence says, “This is today’s pace.”

High expression:
- Lives a consistent daily rhythm that others can entrain to.
- Accepts people’s extremes without judgment; loves humanity as it is.
- Adjusts tempo to the environment while keeping an inner baseline.

Low expression / distortion:
- Forcing one’s schedule on everyone else.
- Getting lost in extremes (too much, too fast, too intense) with no stable pattern from Gate 5.
- Resenting interruptions to the flow, becoming rigid instead of rhythmic.

Why it matters in Collective Logic:
- Logic needs **repeatable conditions**; Gate 5 supplies them.
- Humanity is **not** uniform; Gate 15 embraces the range.
- This channel says: “We can have reliable patterns and still love human diversity.”

Practical notes for your HD JSON corpus:
- Tag for themes: natural timing, daily routine, environmental modulation, love-of-humanity, extremes-with-rhythm.
- Works well beside 15–10 or 46–29 in charts where embodiment and rhythm are a life lesson.
